This methodology is applicable because: (1) land in the project area qualified as forest at least 10 years before the project start date; (2) no peat soils are present on the project site; (3) project proponents can show ownership of the project site and ownership of the carbon rights for the project area; (4) baseline deforestation in the project area falls within the category of planned deforestation (VCS category APD); (5) baselines shall be renewed every 10 years after the start of the project except where triggers lead to a more frequent renewal; (6) no areas registered under the CDM or any other carbon trading scheme are included within the project site.

auditor_team_names_and_positions Klaus Geiger, Project Manager and Lead Auditor, Rainforest Alliance; auditor_qualifications Klaus Geiger is a forester with professional experience in Latin America. As Carbon Services Staff Auditor with Rainforest Alliance Klaus conducts and leads carbon field audits for projects under six different carbon standards, including AFOLU, REDD+, and the VCS Double Approval Methodology. Prior to working with Rainforest Alliance, Klaus researched Sri Lankan non-timber forest products by documenting species composition and mapping spatial distribution in traditional agroforestry gardens, co-managed the 8,000 acre FSC-Certified Yale School Forest, promoted sustainable agriculture techniques for 3.3 years with the Peace Corps in Panama within the Comarca Ngäbe-Buglé and on the national level. Among other experiences, cruised timber for the U.S. Forest Service in Tahoe National Park. Klaus received his Masters of Forestry degree from the Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, and holds a Bachelors of Forestry from University of Missouri-Columbia. Klaus is fluent in Spanish and conversational in Sinhala.

Legal testimony on archaeological evidence reviewed by the audit team does not clearly link historical inhabitation of the area by indigenous populations with modern day local communities. Nevertheless, surrounding communities earn their livelihoods through a mixture of ecotourism, subsistence farming, and small scale agricultural market participation. Some of the neighboring communities do apparently derive part of their livelihoods through activities which are no longer permitted within the project area (e.g. illegal firewood and/or NTFP collection). Though these activities do threaten the permanence of the carbon stocks found within the project area, they are unlikely to affect more than 50% of the stocks on which GHG credits have previously been issued. The property caretaker and patrolmen are the employees that have the most direct interaction with the public, and they are entirely staffed by members of the neighboring communities. col_2 This report represents the final VCS Verification Audit Report for the Boden Creek Ecological Preserve Forest Carbon Project, for which Boden Creek Ecological Preserve is the proponent. The audit team, after extensive desk review, stakeholder interviews, field visit and observation, identified 06 Non- conformances, and 06 Observations communicated in this report through Nonconformity Reports (NCRs) and Observations (OBSs) in Appendix 1. The Non-conformances were successfully resolved and the project’s stated emissions reductions for the January 1st 2011 - Dec 31st 2015 5 have been verified to be free of material error to a reasonable degree of assurance. Project activities focus on forest protection, but include meeting with the local stakeholders surrounding the project area, engaging government officials and local NGOs, implementing the REDD project management and monitoring plans with the help of local partners and contracted staff, undertaking a periodic forest carbon inventory, and modelling deforestation. Activities implemented as part of the project to reduce deforestation include community outreach and employment of local community members as project forest guards or other project staff positions. The scope of the verification included the GHG project implementation; physical infrastructure, activities, technologies and processes of the GHG project; GHG sources, sinks and/or reservoirs; types of GHG’s; and time periods covered. The geographic verification scope was defined by the project boundary, the selected carbon pools, management activities, growth and yield models, forest inventory program, and contract periods. The audit process commenced on January 30th, 2017 with review of the project documentation by the audit team. The proponent provided the audit team with complete and well-justified documentation including the VCS Monitoring and Implementation Report (MIR) for the January 1st 2011 – December 31st 2015 monitoring period, and several dozen supporting documents. Following the pre-field audit document review and sampling plan development, the audit team conducted the field audit from March 20-23, 2017. Field audit activities included direct on-site observations, document review, and stakeholder interviews with local peoples, proponent staff, implementing partner staff, and relevant national government officials. Rainforest Alliance issued the draft audit report for the BCEP VCS verification on 14 April 2017. The project proponent developed responses to all identified Non- Conformity Reports (NCRs) and submitted them to the audit team on May 2nd. The Rainforest Alliance audit team then undertook a second review of project documentation and evidence provided by the project proponent, to which the project proponent responded by June 25th. A third review by Rainforest Alliance was completed, to which the project proponent responded by August 4th. Rainforest Alliance conducted a 4th review, and completed an internal report review on September 22nd. The audit team leader was a Rainforest Alliance Senior Carbon Auditor.

col_1 Ian Starr, Senior Internal Reviewer (RRA Reviewer), Rainforest Alliance; developing_a_plantation_growth_and_yield_model_for_the_center_for_tropical_research_and_education_(catie)_in_costa_rica,_and_preparing_forest_management_plans_for_the_honduran_forestry_development_cooperation._david_earned_his_phd_in_quantitative_forest_management_from_north_carolina_state_university,_where_he_conducted_spatial_optimization_analysis_for_wildlife_and_timber._he_holds_an_m.s._in_natural_resource_management_from_humboldt_state_university_and_his_b.a._in_environmental_biology_from_university_of_california,_santa_barbara._david_is_fluent_in_spanish. Ian’s role as Climate Technical Specialist in Rainforest Alliance’s Climate Program involves being an auditor for REDD+ projects for the voluntary carbon market, providing training on REDD+ and climate change to a broad range of groups worldwide, and providing technical leadership on adaptation and mitigation for agriculture and forestry projects. Ian is a forester and resource manager with personal and professional experience in North America, Central and South America, and Africa. His principal interests lie in improving conservation and forest management practices in tropical forests. He has collaborated on a variety of forestry and natural resource management projects in both Amazonia, and the temperate hardwood forests of the Northeastern United States. These projects have included modelling the carbon sequestration potential of various tropical agroforestry systems and designing and participating in several forest inventories in New England to plan timber sales based on natural regeneration. Ian received his Masters degree in Forestry from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies with a focus on tropical forest and resource management, and received his B.A. from Colgate University where he concentrated in Native American Studies with focus on Central and South America. He is fluent in Spanish and Portuguese.

The project should engage stakeholders proactively to ensure positive community relations and reduce prohibited activities in the area.
The project secured 100% of the funding needed and is already breakeven, with a long‑term financial strategy including an endowment covering implementation costs.
The project should maintain records of incidents such as trespassing and illegal dumping to monitor and reduce unauthorized activity.
The project has an external risk score of 0, indicating no identified external risks.
Extreme weather events such as floods, droughts, and winds are infrequent, with hurricanes occurring roughly every 50 to 100 years, indicating low risk.
The project area’s high tree species diversity and lack of recorded pest or disease attacks reduce the risk of catastrophic disturbance.
Political risk is assessed as zero, indicating no expected government appropriation of private land for redistribution.
A Carbon Management and Agency Agreement obligates the project to observe the monitoring plan and restrict property use, ensuring compliance with project standards.
The ERP Environmental Fund manages overall implementation, monitoring, reporting, and verification, supporting project integrity.
In 2013, the project area experienced a net carbon stock increase of 202.6 units due to deforestation, with no net change from degradation or natural disturbance.
Greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation and degradation activities were 8.4 units, while overall net greenhouse gas emissions under the project scenario were 211.0 units.
